abstract.text: The CLEO-c Experiment has made several recent contributions to the study of charmonium decays. This review briefly outlines the CLEO-c analyses of charmonium that were completed or made public during 2010. Special attention is given to the discovery of the process e + e − → π + π − hc at a center of mass energy of 4170 MeV.

body_text.text: Introduction

Despite the conclusion of data-taking in 2008, the CLEO-c Experiment -which utilizes symmetric e + e − collisions in the charmonium region provided by the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR) -continues to have an active program in the analysis of charmonium data. Recent CLEO-c studies include: (1) measurements of the branching fractions of χ cJ → ppπ 0 , ppη, and ppω 1 ; (2) studies of ψ(2S) decays to γpp, ppπ 0 , and ppη and a confirmation of the BESII observation of the X(1870), a pp threshold enhancement in J/ψ → γpp 2 ; (3) a search for the radiative transition ψ(2S) → γη c (2S) 3 ; (4) measurements of the higher order multipoles in the radiative transitions ψ(2S) → γχ c1,2 and χ c1,2 → γJ/ψ 4 ; and (5) the discovery of the process e + e − → π + π − h c at a center of mass energy of 4170 MeV (preliminary). In the following, each study is briefly reviewed.
Branching Fractions for χ cJ → ppπ 0 , ppη, and ppω

body_text.section: Branching Fractions for χ cJ → ppπ 0 , ppη, and ppω
body_text.text: Starting with the full sample of 25.9 million ψ(2S) decays, CLEO-c measured the branching fractions for χ cJ → ppπ 0 , ppη, and ppω 1 . These results are important inputs to predictions of the related charmonium production rates (pp → (cc) + X, where X is a hadron) that will be studied by the PANDA experiment at GSI. In addition, the Dalitz plots of χ c0,1 → ppπ 0 have been studied (Figure 1). An enhancement in pp mass appears, which is inconsistent with both predictions from the meson emission model 5 and the X(1870) threshold enhancement 6 .

body_text.section: Branching Fractions for χ cJ → ppπ 0 , ppη, and ppω
body_text.text: In addition to the χ cJ decays discussed above, CLEO-c has also measured the branching fractions of ψ(2S) decays to final states involving a pp pair 2 . The Dalitz plots of ppπ 0 and ppη show evidence for the production of a number of N * resonances in π 0 p and ηp, but do not show evidence for a pp threshold enhancement consistent with the X(1870). The X(1870) is also not seen in the ψ(2S) radiative decay to pp. However, evidence is found for the X(1870) through the process ψ(2S) → π + π − J/ψ; J/ψ → γX(1870); X(1870) → pp, which provides confirmation of the original BESII discovery 6 .

Higher-order Multipole Amplitudes in Charmonium Radiative Transitions

body_text.section: Higher-order Multipole Amplitudes in Charmonium Radiative Transitions
body_text.text: The radiative decays ψ(2S) → γχ c1,2 and χ c1,2 → γJ/ψ are dominated by electric dipole (E1) amplitudes, but are expected to have small additional contributions from the higher-order magnetic quadrupole (M2) amplitudes. The relative contributions of the M2 amplitudes are, at least in principle, sensitive to the anomalous magnetic moment of the charm quark. CLEO performed a high-statistics analysis of this process using the decay chains ψ(2S) → γχ cJ ; χ cJ → γJ/ψ; J/ψ → l + l − (l = e, µ) for J = 1, 2, using clean samples of approximately 40 000 events for J = 1 and approximately 20 000 events for J = 2 4 , significantly larger event samples than previous measurements. Using an unbinned maximum likelihood fit to angular distributions, CLEO found the following normalized M2 admixtures:

There is clear evidence for non-zero M2 amplitudes (left plot of Figure 5). These new measurements agree well with theoretical expectations when the anomalous magnetic moment of the charm quark is assumed to be zero and the mass of the charm quark is assumed to be 1.5 GeV/c 2 , as shown in the right plot of Figure 5.
Transitions to the h c Above DD Threshold

body_text.section: Transitions to the h c Above DD Threshold
body_text.text: Finally, CLEO-c has presented preliminary results on the observation of e + e − → π + π − h c at a center of mass energy of 4170 MeV. This builds upon a previous analysis of CLEO-c to study the e + e − → XJ/ψ (X = π + π − , π 0 π 0 , K + K − , etc.) cross sections as a function of center of mass energy 7 . In that analysis a rise in the cross section at 4260 MeV for both the π + π − J/ψ and π 0 π 0 J/ψ reactions was attributed to the Y (4260), a charmonium hybrid meson candidate first discovered by BaBar 8 . Since that analysis, CLEO-c has collected a total of 586 pb −1 of data at 4170 MeV, about twenty times larger than the data sets used to search for XJ/ψ between 4120 and 4200 MeV. Using this larger data set, CLEO-c has made the first observation of e + e − → π + π − h c at 4170 MeV and has searched for e + e − → π + π − h c in the original scan data, which spans energies from 3970 to 4260 MeV.

body_text.text: All final state particles were detected and the sum of their four-momenta was constrained to the four-momentum of the initial e + e − system. The quality (χ 2 ) of this kinematic fit was used to select events. The η c was selected by requiring the recoil mass of the γπ + π − system be within 50 MeV/c 2 of the η c mass. Then the π + π − recoil mass was used to isolate the π + π − h c signal.

The right plot of Figure 3 shows the same figure except now restricted to those decay modes of the η c that have measured branching fractions. Here there are 74±11 events with a 7.7σ significance. This corresponds to a cross section of e + e − → π + π − h c of 12.2 ± 1.8 ± 2.4 ± 4.0 pb, where the first error is statistical, the second is systematic, and the third is due to the errors on the external measurements of the η c branching fractions and the branching fraction of h c → γη c . For reference, the cross section for e + e − → π + π − J/ψ at 4170 MeV is 8 ± 2 ± 2 pb.

body_text.text: To obtain a scan of the π + π − h c cross section as a function of center of mass energy, the same procedure was followed using the smaller samples of scan data. Following the XJ/ψ scan 7 , the data is divided into three bins: 3970 − 4060; 4120 − 4200; and 4260MeV. Figure 4 shows the resulting π + π − h c cross section as a function of center of mass energy. The π + π − J/ψ results are included for reference. There is perhaps a suggestive rise at 4260 MeV, but more data is clearly needed.
